Creating Test Data for Grants Claim Submissions

  • Show All Code
  • Hide All Code
  • View Source
R
Data Analysis
Data Visualization
Published

April 22, 2024

In this blog post I outline the steps I took to create a test data set to verify the functionality of a tracking system I created for the Oregon Department of Education (ODE).

Introduction

The Federal Systems Team is piloting a new Summer Learning Grant Program to support historically undeserved students, backed by House Bill (HB) 4082 and $30 million in funding. With a requirement for detailed expenditure reports, the program aims to ensure equitable access to high-quality summer programming.

To aid in this process I developed a collaborative tracking system in Google Sheets (as requested) to help monitor how often districts are submitting claims and what issues (if any) arise. To show and verify functionality I created a mock data set in R, that would satisfy certain criteria. In this post I am going to discuss how I created that data set, and then make a quick reactable table so you can view the data set further without having to follow these steps yourself.

Requirements

Since the original ask was a tracking system I had the requirements for the tracking system, but then needed to create the requirements for the test data set. After that I identified the key data columns I would be defining in the test data set.

  • Contents
  • Tracking System Requiremenets
  • Test Data Requirements
  • Test Data Columns

Tabs

  • Tracking System Requirements

  • Test Data Requirements

  • Test Data Columns

The tracking system developed needed to include the following:

  • Grantee name and lead contact

  • Grantee type (e.g., district, ESD, consortium)

  • Date of submission

  • Submission cycle (i.e. weekly, monthly, quarterly)

  • Total amount of claim

  • Status of claim

  • Issues or questions about the expenditure report

  • Contact information for the grantee

The test data needed to include:

  • Entries for 10 different grantees to ensure a variety of data points.

  • Varying frequencies of submission cycles, including weekly, monthly, and quarterly submissions.

  • Different types of grantees such as districts, educational service districts (ESD), and consortiums.

  • Claim statuses should include a mix of ‘Approved’, ‘Pending Review’, and ‘Needs Revision’.

  • Incorporate a range of issues or questions related to expenditure reports to evaluate how the system tracks and flags potential problems.

  • Ensure that every grantee entry includes complete contact information.

  • Date of submissions should span across several months within the year 2024, to test the system’s performance over different reporting periods.

  • The total value of all claims does not exceed $30 million.

Test Data Columns

  • Grantee Name

  • Lead Contact

  • Grantee Type

  • Date of Submission

  • Submission Cycle

  • Total Amount of Claim

  • Status of Claim

  • Issues or Questions

  • Contact Information

Setup

For the setup I started by loading the necessary packages, created a data frame for grant submission, defined constants, and then created a data set of 10 grantees.

  • Contents
  • Load Packaged
  • Constants

  • Define Constant

Load two packages:

  • dplyr to mutate the data.

  • lubridate to …

  • skimr to check assumptions about the data.

  • reactable to create interactive web tables.

Hide code 
base::library(dplyr)
base::library(lubridate)
base::library(skimr)
base::library(reactable)

The only constant to define is 30 million for the total budget. In the future this might want to be broken into a monthly or quartly budget as the program grows.

Hide code 
total_budget <- 30000000

Define Initial Data Sets

There will be two datasets that we will be manipualting, so I need to first define those data sets.

Tabs

  • Define Initial Grants Data

  • Verify Assumptions

  • Define Initial Grantees Data

To have an idea of what the data set needs to look like I defined an initially empty data set grants1.

Hide code 
grants <- data.frame(
  GranteeName = character(),
  LeadContact = character(),
  GranteeType = character(),
  DateOfSubmission = character(),
  SubmissionCycle = character(),
  TotalAmountOfClaim = numeric(),
  StatusOfClaim = character(),
  IssuesOrQuestions = character(),
  ContactInformation = character()
)

From there use the dplyr package and mutate() function to change:

  • Date of Submission to a date type.

  • Redefine SubmissionCycle and StatusOfClaim as factor types.

Hide code 
grants <- grants |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    DateOfSubmission = base::as.Date(DateOfSubmission),
    SubmissionCycle = base::factor(
      SubmissionCycle, 
      levels = c("Annual", "Semi-Annual", "Quarterly")),
    StatusOfClaim = base::factor(
      StatusOfClaim, 
      levels = c("Pending", "Approved", "Rejected"))
  )

Lets now use the skimr package to verify that these changes were made.

Hide code 
skim_grants <- skimr::skim(grants)
summary(skim_grants)
Data summary
Name grants
Number of rows 0
Number of columns 9
_______________________
Column type frequency:
character 5
Date 1
factor 2
numeric 1
________________________
Group variables None

Our test data set will be based on 10 grantees, which are define here such that there are:

  • 10 Grantees

  • Variation of Types

  • Variation of Frequency

  • Submission date is defined based on reporting frequency

  • Number of claims defined by reporting frequency

Hide code 
grantee_data <- base::data.frame(
  GranteeName = paste("Grantee", 1:10),
  GranteeType = c(
    "District", "ESD", "Consortium", 
    "District", "ESD", "Consortium", 
    "District", "ESD", "Consortium", 
    "District"),
  ReportingFrequency = c(
    "Monthly", "Weekly", "Quarterly", 
    "Monthly", "Weekly", "Quarterly", 
    "Monthly", "Weekly", "Quarterly", 
    "Monthly"),
  StartDate = base::as.Date(c(
    "2024-01-01", "2024-01-07", "2024-03-01", 
    "2024-01-01", "2024-01-07", "2024-03-01", 
    "2024-01-01", "2024-01-07", "2024-03-01", 
    "2024-01-01")),
  NumClaims = c(
    12, 52, 4, 
    12, 52, 4, 
    12, 52, 4, 
    12)
)

To verify this data set I will simply eyeball it to verify my assumptions for each column.

Grantee Claim Amounts

Each Grantee needs a piece of the 30 million dollar pie, so to define this randomly:

  • Define a random normalized percent to each grantee.

  • Define a max claim using the normalized percentage and total_budge constant.

  • Define an average claim using the max claim and NumClaims column of the grantee1 data.

  • Define Random Percentes
  • Define Max Claim
  • Define Average Claim

Create the function rand_norm_perc() which will assign a random percent value to each grantee and then normalize it.

Hide code 
rand_norm_perc <- function(n) {
  base::set.seed(123) 
  rand_perc <- stats::runif(n, min = 0, max = 100)
  norm_perc <- rand_perc / base::sum(rand_perc)
  return(norm_perc)
}

Then generate random normalized percentages for each grantee.

Hide code 
rand_percents <- rand_norm_perc(base::nrow(grantee_data))

This is the maximum amount that each grantee can spend. Meaning that sum of all their claims for that year cannot exceed this value.

Hide code 
grantee_data$MaxClaim <- base::round(rand_percents * total_budget, digits = 2)

Not doing anything too cute here, just dividing the max claim by the number of claims the grantee should submit that year.

Hide code 
grantee_data$AvgClaim <- grantee_data$MaxClaim / grantee_data$NumClaims

Verify grantee_data

Before we get too far lets check that the data is how we want it loves.

Hide code 
grantee_data
   GranteeName GranteeType ReportingFrequency  StartDate NumClaims  MaxClaim
1    Grantee 1    District            Monthly 2024-01-01        12 1491978.0
2    Grantee 2         ESD             Weekly 2024-01-07        52 4089797.9
3    Grantee 3  Consortium          Quarterly 2024-03-01         4 2121809.0
4    Grantee 4    District            Monthly 2024-01-01        12 4581173.6
5    Grantee 5         ESD             Weekly 2024-01-07        52 4879228.8
6    Grantee 6  Consortium          Quarterly 2024-03-01         4  236351.2
7    Grantee 7    District            Monthly 2024-01-01        12 2739858.7
8    Grantee 8         ESD             Weekly 2024-01-07        52 4629950.2
9    Grantee 9  Consortium          Quarterly 2024-03-01         4 2860894.4
10  Grantee 10    District            Monthly 2024-01-01        12 2368958.3
    AvgClaim
1  124331.50
2   78649.96

So far so good. We have:

  • 10 Grantees

  • Mix of grantee types

  • Mix of reporting frequency

  • Start dates

  • Max number of claims submitted (for the year): 4, 12, or 52

  • The sum of all max claims is equal to or less than 30 million

Hide code 
base::sum(grantee_data$MaxClaim)
[1] 3e+07

Submission Functions

Now that we have the grantees and their claim amounts defined we can build out the submission by:

  • Contents
  • Define Submission Dates
  • Define Random Status Function
  • Define Random Issues Function

Tabs:

  • Define Submission Dates

Create the function submission_dates() to generate submission dates based on reporting frequency.

Hide code 
submission_dates <- function(
    start_date, 
    freq, 
    num_claims
    ) {
  if (freq == "Weekly") {
    return(base::seq(
      from = start_date, 
      by = "7 days", 
      length.out = num_claims)
      )
  } else if (freq == "Monthly") {
    return(base::seq(
      from = start_date, 
      by = "1 month", 
      length.out = num_claims)
      )
  } else if (freq == "Quarterly") {
    return(base::seq(
      from = start_date, 
      by = "3 months", 
      length.out = num_claims)
      )
  }
}

Create the function random_status to generate a random status for each submission.

Hide code 
random_status <- function(n) {
  statuses <- c("Approved", "Pending Review", "Needs Revision")
  return(sample(statuses, n, replace = TRUE))
}

Create the function random_issues to generate a random issue status for each submission.

Hide code 
# Function to generate random issues or questions
random_issues <- function(n) {
  issues <- c("No issues", "Minor discrepancies", "Major discrepancies")
  return(sample(issues, n, replace = TRUE))
}

Build Up Test Data

Finally, now is time to actually use all the functions and intial data sets to create the test data set.

In this blog post I outline the steps I took to create a test data set to verify the functionality of a tracking system I created for the [Oregon Department of Education (ODE)](https://www.oregon.gov/ode/pages/default.aspx). 

# Introduction 

The Federal Systems Team is piloting a new Summer Learning Grant Program to support historically undeserved students, backed by [House Bill (HB) 4082](https://olis.oregonlegislature.gov/liz/2024R1/Downloads/MeasureDocument/HB4082/Enrolled) and \$30 million in funding. With a requirement for detailed expenditure reports, the program aims to ensure equitable access to high-quality summer programming. 

To aid in this process I developed a collaborative tracking system in Google Sheets (as requested) to help monitor how often districts are submitting claims and what issues (if any) arise. To show and verify functionality I created a mock data set in R, that would satisfy certain criteria. In this post I am going to discuss how I created that data set, and then make a quick reactable table so you can view the data set further without having to follow these steps yourself. 

# Requirements 

Since the original ask was a tracking system I had the requirements for the tracking system, but then needed to create the requirements for the test data set. After that I identified the key data columns I would be defining in the test data set. 

::: panel-tabset

## Contents

**Tabs**

- Test Data Requirements

## Tracking System Requiremenets 

The tracking system developed needed to include the following:

-   Grantee name and lead contact

-   Grantee type (e.g., district, ESD, consortium)

-   Date of submission

-   Submission cycle (i.e. weekly, monthly, quarterly)

-   Total amount of claim

-   Status of claim

-   Issues or questions about the expenditure report

-   Contact information for the grantee
    
## Test Data Requirements

The test data needed to include: 

-   Entries for **10 different grantees** to ensure a variety of data points.

-   Varying frequencies of submission cycles, including weekly, monthly, and quarterly submissions.

-   Different types of grantees such as districts, educational service districts (ESD), and consortiums.

-   Claim statuses should include a mix of 'Approved', 'Pending Review', and 'Needs Revision'.

-   Incorporate a range of issues or questions related to expenditure reports to evaluate how the system tracks and flags potential problems.

-   Ensure that every grantee entry includes complete contact information.

-   Date of submissions should span across several months within the year 2024, to test the system's performance over different reporting periods.

-   The total value of all claims does not exceed \$30 million.

## Test Data Columns

Test Data Columns

- Grantee Name

- Lead Contact

- Grantee Type

- Date of Submission

- Submission Cycle

- Total Amount of Claim

- Status of Claim

- Issues or Questions

- Contact Information

# Define Initial Data Sets

There will be two datasets that we will be manipualting, so I need to first define those data sets. 

::: panel-tabset

## Contents

## Define Initial Grants Data

To have an idea of what the data set needs to look like I defined an initially empty data set `grants1`. 

```{r create data frame}
grants <- data.frame(
  GranteeName = character(),
  LeadContact = character(),
  GranteeType = character(),
  DateOfSubmission = character(),
  SubmissionCycle = character(),
  TotalAmountOfClaim = numeric(),
  StatusOfClaim = character(),
  IssuesOrQuestions = character(),
  ContactInformation = character()
)
```

From there use the `dplyr` package and `mutate()` function to change:

- Date of Submission to a date type. 

- Redefine `SubmissionCycle` and `StatusOfClaim` as factor types. 

```{r convert columns}
grants <- grants |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    DateOfSubmission = base::as.Date(DateOfSubmission),
    SubmissionCycle = base::factor(
      SubmissionCycle, 
      levels = c("Annual", "Semi-Annual", "Quarterly")),
    StatusOfClaim = base::factor(
      StatusOfClaim, 
      levels = c("Pending", "Approved", "Rejected"))
  )
```

## Verify Assumptions

Lets now use the `skimr` package to verify that these changes were made. 

```{r}
skim_grants <- skimr::skim(grants)
summary(skim_grants)
```


## Grantees Defined

Our test data set will be based on 10 grantees, which are define here such that there are: 

- 10 Grantees

- Variation of Types

- Variation of Frequency 

- Submission date is defined based on reporting frequency 

- Number of claims defined by reporting frequency 

```{r define grantee_data}
grantee_data <- base::data.frame(
  GranteeName = paste("Grantee", 1:10),
  GranteeType = c(
    "District", "ESD", "Consortium", 
    "District", "ESD", "Consortium", 
    "District", "ESD", "Consortium", 
    "District"),
  ReportingFrequency = c(
    "Monthly", "Weekly", "Quarterly", 
    "Monthly", "Weekly", "Quarterly", 
    "Monthly", "Weekly", "Quarterly", 
    "Monthly"),
  StartDate = base::as.Date(c(
    "2024-01-01", "2024-01-07", "2024-03-01", 
    "2024-01-01", "2024-01-07", "2024-03-01", 
    "2024-01-01", "2024-01-07", "2024-03-01", 
    "2024-01-01")),
  NumClaims = c(
    12, 52, 4, 
    12, 52, 4, 
    12, 52, 4, 
    12)
)
```

## Verify Grantees

To verify this data set I will simply eyeball it to verify my assumptions for each column.

```{r}
grantee_data
```

# Grantee Claim Amounts

Each Grantee needs a piece of the 30 million dollar pie, so to define this randomly: 

- Define a random normalized percent to each grantee.

- Define a max claim using the normalized percentage and `total_budge` constant. 

- Define an average claim using the max claim and `NumClaims` column of the `grantee1` data. 


::: panel-tabset

## Define Random Percentes 

Create the function `rand_norm_perc()` which will assign a random percent value to each grantee and then normalize it. 

```{r random percentage function }
rand_norm_perc <- function(n) {
  base::set.seed(123) 
  rand_perc <- stats::runif(n, min = 0, max = 100)
  norm_perc <- rand_perc / base::sum(rand_perc)
  return(norm_perc)
}
```

Then generate random normalized percentages for each grantee.

```{r}
rand_percents <- rand_norm_perc(base::nrow(grantee_data))
```

## Define Max Claim

This is the maximum amount that each grantee can spend. Meaning that sum of all their claims for that year cannot exceed this value. 

```{r define MaxClaim}
grantee_data$MaxClaim <- base::round(rand_percents * total_budget, digits = 2)
```

## Define Average Claim 

Not doing anything too cute here, just dividing the max claim by the number of claims the grantee should submit that year.

```{r}
grantee_data$AvgClaim <- grantee_data$MaxClaim / grantee_data$NumClaims
```

#  Verify `grantee_data`

Before we get too far lets check that the data is how we want it loves. 

```{r}
grantee_data
```


So far so good. We have:

- 10 Grantees

- Mix of grantee types

- Mix of reporting frequency 

- Start dates

- Max number of claims submitted (for the year): 4, 12, or 52

- The sum of all max claims is equal to or less than 30 million

```{r sum maxclaim}
base::sum(grantee_data$MaxClaim)
```

:::

# Submission Functions

Now that we have the grantees and their claim amounts defined we can build out the submission by: 

- 


::: panel-tabset

## Contents

**Tabs:**

- Define Submission Dates

## Define Submission Dates

Create the function `submission_dates()` to generate submission dates based on reporting frequency.

```{r generate submission dates function}
submission_dates <- function(
    start_date, 
    freq, 
    num_claims
    ) {
  if (freq == "Weekly") {
    return(base::seq(
      from = start_date, 
      by = "7 days", 
      length.out = num_claims)
      )
  } else if (freq == "Monthly") {
    return(base::seq(
      from = start_date, 
      by = "1 month", 
      length.out = num_claims)
      )
  } else if (freq == "Quarterly") {
    return(base::seq(
      from = start_date, 
      by = "3 months", 
      length.out = num_claims)
      )
  }
}
```

## Define Random Status Function

Create the function `random_status` to generate a random status for each submission. 

```{r}
random_status <- function(n) {
  statuses <- c("Approved", "Pending Review", "Needs Revision")
  return(sample(statuses, n, replace = TRUE))
}
```

## Define Random Issues Function

Create the function `random_issues` to generate a random issue status for each submission. 

```{r}
# Function to generate random issues or questions
random_issues <- function(n) {
  issues <- c("No issues", "Minor discrepancies", "Major discrepancies")
  return(sample(issues, n, replace = TRUE))
}
```

:::
